prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the author of this situation is in the wrong. The context is that the author and their girlfriend live together, and he pays all the bills. She works part-time, so maybe he's been covering everything because she can't afford it. Then there was an incident where he forgot his wallet and asked her to pay for takeout under $40. She reacted negatively, which made him upset, and now he's considering making her start paying some bills as a matter of principle.

First, I need to analyze both sides. The author is frustrated because he's been paying all the expenses, and he feels that this one incident showed that she's not contributing. On the other hand, the girlfriend works part-time, so her income might be limited. If she has no expenses, maybe she's already using her income for her own needs, and being asked to pay for an unexpected takeout might be a stretch for her financially.

The key points here are financial responsibility and communication. The author might be overreacting by wanting her to pay bills over a single incident. It's possible that his frustration stems from an underlying issue where he feels his contributions aren't appreciated. However, expecting her to pay for something that's a minor expense might not be fair if her income is significantly lower. Also, the way he made her pay it without prior discussion could be the root of her bad reaction. 

In relationships, splitting expenses isn't just about money but also about fairness and mutual respect. The author should probably have a conversation about how they handle finances together, considering her part-time job and his full-time one. But in this case, he's reacting to a single event and deciding to change the arrangement without discussing it. That might not be fair. Also, the tone he uses in the question (like "some fucking take out") shows frustration, but that doesn't negate the need for a fair approach. 

So, is he in the wrong? Well, if he's been the sole provider until now because that's the agreement they had, then expecting her to pay for something small because of one incident could be seen as unfair. The problem might not just be the incident but the way he's handling it. The right approach would be to discuss shared responsibilities and maybe adjust based on their incomes rather than punishing her for a one-time thing. Therefore, the answer might be A, that he's in the wrong because he's overreacting without proper communication. But I need to check if there's a cultural or situational nuance I'm missing. In some relationships, splitting expenses is expected, even if one partner earns more. But if the agreement was for him to pay everything, maybe she didn't expect to contribute. The author's action of making her pay without prior discussion could have been a trigger. So, yes, he's in the wrong for not addressing the issue with open communication and instead using a single incident to change the financial arrangement. The answer is A.
